content.description: SDS on the good jug slot. Powerful moves up through the sidepull and left into the finish of Well Worked.
content.location: Starts below "Well Worked" sort of laydown just to the right on a microwave sized block.

content.description: Same start as BTS but go straight out the same finish as Darcy's Law Direct.
content.location: Similar start to Darcy's Law but just to the right. This sets the climber up easier to get into the direct finish out the roof easier than DLD.

content.description: Stand start on right hand side pull, left hand slot. Step the feet on and do a blind barn-door dead point to the slot and then roll out left for the top out.
content.location: Wellhead (Stand) is the ending of Darcy's Law Direct.

content.description: Higher start to Well Worked. Psuedo-SDS/Laydown on a microwave sized block with L-Hand on low 3-finger gaston and R-Hand on a high right side pull. Make a powerful move up and left to a good crimper and topout.
content.location: Furthest left problem at the cellar. Tops out as a common finish for many of the cellar problems.

content.description: A lot on techy movement reminding me of some HP40 boulders like Skeletor or Odd Job. SDS same as Slug and move left reversing the Bottom's Up sequence and finishing on Worked Over. *Has also been done with Nipple Up ending @ ~essentially the same grade but left ending is just 1notch more enduro.
content.location: SDS on the left side of the Center of the Cellar and Nipple Down.

content.description: SDS on a flat ledge. move into a huge jug side pull and then three phase bump to top.
SDS on a good side pull and a jug. Move up into good pockets in a seam and move out right hand to a slopey crimp. Set up and fire to the lip.
SDS on a right hand 2 finger pocket and left on a variety of slopers. move up to the platform and the pocket and topout out straight up. Classic for the area.
SDS on good holds. throw up and left to a good sloper runnel and work up the water groove to top out.
SDS/Squat start on crimps on the rightside of the refrigerator sized column feature. Make a move up to jug seam and then big moves on jugs to an awesome top out!
SDS the same as Three Phase Flow and move left into the finish of Surface Casing.
Squat start on a good jug. make a big deapoint or dyno to a good open handed hold and head straight up.

Various methods exist but all seem to leave you coming up short on sticking the move. A crucial foot broke making this problem much more difficult before FA.SDS on L-Hand flat good crimp with optional thumb catch and R-Hand gaston. Pull feet on and either try to figure out a way to use various options under the lip or go big L-Hand to the crazy thin beaded crimp and then fire huge R-Hand to the start of Nipple Down Stand and topout.Guessing this is somewhere between V8-10. Dependent on hold sequence, finger strength, and body size. Good NE Arkansas Testpiece.
content.location: A body length or so Climber's left outside of the main Cellar and Darcy's Law.

content.description: Awesome Movement. Horsepens Style in East Ark!!SDS same as Worked Over but get matched on the high crescent and do a powerful L-Hand gaston press up and right to a sloper and then HP40 style sloper downpressing and mantle tech to surmount the top.

Stand Start in the "Smiley Face" crescent with L-Hand on leftside and R-Hand on rightside crimp or switch hand positions for the start and start preparing for the sequence coming in from Nipple Down SDS.
SDS with the 2finger pocket as a left hand and right on a slopey crimper. Dyno to the ledge and then topout the same as Surface Casing.
SDS on Sidepull/gaston and crimps with a big skirt for feet and climb straight up the wall on good crimps and feet to an easy topout.
Sds on Blowing the Stack and move right into the start of Rat Hole. Just 3 moves makes Rat Hole much harder.
Start on Darcy's Law and finish on the powerful compression ending of Wellhead. Very continuous compression to the end. Probably is the line on the boulder.
content.location: Compression SDS on the left side of the cave.

content.description: SDS with left hand on a good 3 finger crimp or a sloper, right hand on the 2finger crimp/pinch at the start of BTS. Make tenuous compression moves up a right hand corner and left hand sloper crimp rail to get into the finish of Blowing the Stack. TESTPIECE
content.location: Compression SDS on the far left side of the cave.

content.description: Right most sds. Start on L-Hand good sidepull and feet under the roof. Makes moves up to a good horizontal slot and then easy but semi-tall top out. Optional to move right and top out the same as 540 D/C traverse ending.

SDS on crimps on the Left/middle side of the bowl and head up and slightly left. Thin, hard, and shouldery. I have really weak should and fat weak sausage fingers so I imagine this could be far easier for a smaller climber.
SDS on two small crimpers. Keep the tension and move up to two slopers and then a jug topout. This thing is funky and can feel really easy and then buck you the next go round.

SDS on a left hand triangle pinch and a right heel. keep the tension and bump up right to a good side pull. use a variety of crimpers with the left hand to gain the top sloper. topout on jugs. Some really cool movement establishing and moving through the watergroove.
content.location: Starts on independent holds up and right of Worked Over and Nipple Up start jug.

content.description: SDS same as Recirc and TPF. Grab L-Hand pinch or as crimp and make a large deadpoint to a R-Hand sloper and then small L-Hand crimp and topout on the horn feature same as TPF.
Stand start on the R--Hand side pull, L-Hand slot and traverse the seam left and do a very body position specific deadpoint sequence out around the lip and then move on to the face up and left.
SDS on small crimper pinches. Get a good crimp right handed and power up to the seam. Traverse out left and stick the dead point/dyno to the breadloaf pinch and top out straight up. CLASSIC.
content.location: SDS using R-hand start of Darcy's Law as a L-Hand. Be careful dynoing and pulling on the big block. It's hollow but I never pulled it off...not saying it's gonna stay up there forever.

content.description: SDS on common start of Three Phase Flow and work right initially using low feet beneath the roof on the skirt and then over the lip as you progress further right. Topout essentially rolls around the corner and steps off on the ground.

Welcome to The Cellar. Home of Darcy's Law (one of the most classic hard boulder problems in Northeast Arkansas)The most concentrated circuit area in the Gasfields - everything tops out here. Bring some brushes, clippers, and loppers to rehab the area since it's been nearly a decade since anyone last climbed here. If you keep an open mind, what you'll discover here is a strange Arkansas proxy to Horsepens/Font style fine grained sandstone on slopers and compression. This will never be a long distance destination but it is a great training zone (especially for those living close by) to have for climbers in the North Eastern/North Central parts of Arkansas. This area can get a lot of sun in the winter time but with the nature of the cave provide shade throughout the day and the cave can also be very sheltered from the wind and conversely, fairly shaded in the spring and fall during leaf-on. The Cellar has been posted on 27crags.com (27crags.com/crags/the-gasfi…) for nearly a decade but it doesn't seems that very many people have ventured into these boulder gardens since the first ascensionist (circa 2011). Assume boulders will need to be recleaned but it'll be worth it and you'll have these little zen gardens of public land all to yourself to session your heart out and finger tips off!
